speakerInfo.speakerBio: Nobel Laureate Al Gore focused the world’s attention on the global climate crisis. Now he’s showing us how we’re moving towards real solutions.

talkTitle: Averting the climate crisis

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Amy Smith designs cheap, practical fixes for tough problems in developing countries. Among her many accomplishments, the MIT engineer received a MacArthur "genius" grant in 2004 and was the first woman to win the Lemelson-MIT Prize for turning her ideas into inventions.

talkTitle: Simple designs to save a life

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ashraf Ghani, Afghanistan’s new president-elect, and his opponent, Abdullah Abdullah, will share power in a national unity government. He previously served as Finance Minister and as a chancellor of Kabul University.

talkTitle: How to rebuild a broken state

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In 2004, legendary spacecraft designer Burt Rutan won the $10M Ansari X-Prize for SpaceShipOne, the first privately funded craft to enter space twice in a two-week period. He's now collaborating with Virgin Galactic to build the first rocketship for space tourism.

talkTitle: The real future of space exploration

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Car design is a ubiquitous but often overlooked art form. As chief of design for the BMW Group, Chris Bangle has overseen cars that have been seen the world over, including BMW 7 Series and the Z4 roadster.

talkTitle: Great cars are great art

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In 2001, Craig Venter made headlines for sequencing the human genome. In 2003, he started mapping the ocean's biodiversity. And now he's created the first synthetic lifeforms -- microorganisms that can produce alternative fuels.

talkTitle: Sampling the ocean's DNA

speakerInfo.speakerBio: David Pogue is the personal technology columnist for the New York Times and a tech correspondent for CBS News. He's also one of the world's bestselling how-to authors, with titles in the For Dummies series and his own line of "Missing Manual" books.

talkTitle: Simplicity sells

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Architect David Rockwell draws on his love of drama and spectacle to create fantastic, high-impact restaurants, cultural facilities, airline terminals, theater sets -- and playgrounds.

talkTitle: A memorial at Ground Zero

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Dean Ornish is a clinical professor at UCSF and founder of the Preventive Medicine Research Institute. He's a leading expert on fighting illness -- particularly heart disease with dietary and lifestyle changes.

talkTitle: The killer American diet that's sweeping the planet

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Eva Vertes is a microbiology prodigy. Her discovery, at age 17, of a compound that stops fruit-fly brain cells from dying was regarded as a step toward curing Alzheimer's. Now she aims to find better ways to treat -- and avoid -- cancer.

talkTitle: Meet the future of cancer research

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A living legend, Frank Gehry has forged his own language of architecture, creating astonishing buildings all over the world, such as the Guggenheim in Bilbao, the Walt Disney Concert Hall in LA, and Manhattan's new IAC building.

talkTitle: A master architect asks, Now what?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Anthropologist Helen Fisher studies gender differences and the evolution of human emotions. She’s best known as an expert on romantic love.

talkTitle: Why we love, why we cheat

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A self-proclaimed nature nerd, Janine Benyus' concept of biomimicry has galvanized scientists, architects, designers and engineers into exploring new ways in which nature's successes can inspire humanity.

talkTitle: Biomimicry's surprising lessons from nature's engineers

speakerInfo.speakerBio: There may be no one better to contemplate the meaning of cultural change than Kevin Kelly, whose life story reads like a treatise on the value and impacts of technology.

talkTitle: How technology evolves

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Detective of fads and emerging subcultures, chronicler of jobs-you-never-knew-existed, Malcolm Gladwell's work is toppling the popular understanding of bias, crime, food, marketing, race, consumers and intelligence.

talkTitle: Choice, happiness and spaghetti sauce

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Mena Trott and her husband Ben founded Six Apart in a spare bedroom after the blogging software they developed grew beyond a hobby. With products Movable Type, TypePad, LiveJournal and Vox, the company has helped lead the "social media" revolution.

talkTitle: Meet the founder of the blog revolution

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Michael Shermer debunks myths, superstitions and urban legends -- and explains why we believe them. Along with publishing Skeptic Magazine, he's author of Why People Believe Weird Things and The Mind of the Market.

talkTitle: Why people believe weird things

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Richard Baraniuk founded Connexions -- now called OpenStax -- a free, open-source, global clearinghouse of course materials. Students and educators tap into its vast store of texts on everything from engineering to ornithology to music, adapting the content as they see fit.

talkTitle: The birth of the open-source learning revolution

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Performance artist and storyteller Rives has been called "the first 2.0 poet," using images, video and technology to bring his words to life.

talkTitle: If I controlled the Internet

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Known as "Captain Organic," Ross Lovegrove embraces nature as the inspiration for his "fat-free" design. Each object he creates -- be it bottle, chair, staircase or car -- is reduced to its essential elements. His pieces offer minimal forms of maximum beauty.

talkTitle: Organic design, inspired by nature

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Seth Godin is an entrepreneur and blogger who thinks about the marketing of ideas in the digital age. His newest interest: the tribes we lead.

talkTitle: How to get your ideas to spread

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Steven Levitt's eye-opening Freakonomics took economic theory into the real world of suburban parenting and urban drug gangs, turning conventional wisdom upside-down.

talkTitle: The freakonomics of crack dealing

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Steven Levitt's eye-opening Freakonomics took economic theory into the real world of suburban parenting and urban drug gangs, turning conventional wisdom upside-down.

talkTitle: Surprising stats about child carseats

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Founder of the influential studio Morphosis, and co-founder of the Southern California Institute of Architecture, Pritzker Prize-winning architect Thom Mayne marries conceptual ideas with form, challenging the way we perceive structure, building and the environment.

talkTitle: How architecture can connect us

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Vik Muniz delights in subverting a viewer's expectations. He uses unexpected materials to create portraits, landscapes and still lifes, which he then photographs.

talkTitle: Art with wire, sugar, chocolate and string

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Strategic planner Thomas Barnett has advised US leaders on national security since the end of the Cold War. His bold ideas about the future of warfare and the military are spelled out in his best-selling book The Pentagon's New Map.

talkTitle: Let's rethink America's military strategy

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Dentist-turned-photographer Phil Borges documents the world's disappearing cultures, capturing portraits of exiled Tibetan monks and many of the world’s embattled tribal and indigenous cultures.

talkTitle: Photos of endangered cultures

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Nobel laureate James Watson took part in one of the most important scientific breakthroughs of the 20th century: the discovery of the structure of DNA. More than 50 years later, he continues to investigate biology's deepest secrets.

talkTitle: How we discovered DNA

speakerInfo.speakerBio: To research his book, "Stealth of Nations," Robert Neuwirth spent four years among street vendors, smugglers and “informal” import/export firms.

talkTitle: The hidden world of shadow cities

speakerInfo.speakerBio: With a vision for a free online encyclopedia, Wales assembled legions of volunteer contributors, gave them tools for collaborating, and created the self-organizing, self-correcting, ever-expanding, multilingual encyclopedia of the future.

talkTitle: The birth of Wikipedia

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ray Kurzweil is an engineer who has radically advanced the fields of speech, text and audio technology. He's revered for his dizzying -- yet convincing -- writing on the advance of technology, the limits of biology and the future of the human species.

talkTitle: The accelerating power of technology

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Aubrey de Grey, British researcher on aging, claims he has drawn a roadmap to defeat biological aging. He provocatively proposes that the first human beings who will live to 1,000 years old have already been born.

talkTitle: A roadmap to end aging

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Frans Lanting is one of the greatest nature photographers of our time. His work has been featured in National Geographic, Audubon andTime, as well as numerous award-winning books. Lanting's recent exhibition, The LIFE Project, offers a lyrical interpretation of the history of life on Earth.

talkTitle: The story of life in photographs

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The founder of the MIT Media Lab, Nicholas Negroponte pushed the edge of the information revolution as an inventor, thinker and angel investor. He's the driving force behind One Laptop per Child, building computers for children in the developing world.

talkTitle: One Laptop per Child

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As a creative director at Ideo, Paul Bennett reminds us that design need not invoke grand gestures or sweeping statements to be successful, but instead can focus on the little things in life, the obvious, the overlooked.

talkTitle: Design is in the details

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Nick Bostrom asks big questions: What should we do, as individuals and as a species, to optimize our long-term prospects? Will humanity’s technological advancements ultimately destroy us?

talkTitle: A philosophical quest for our biggest problems

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Sirena Huang started taking violin lessons at age 4 and made her professional solo debut at 9 with the Taiwan Symphony Orchestra. She has won top prizes in numerous international competitions, delighting audiences worldwide with her virtuosity and charm.

talkTitle: An 11-year-old's magical violin

speakerInfo.speakerBio: David Deutsch's 1997 book "The Fabric of Reality" laid the groundwork for an all-encompassing Theory of Everything, and galvanized interest in the idea of a quantum computer, which could solve problems of hitherto unimaginable complexity.

talkTitle: Chemical scum that dream of distant quasars

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Inventor Saul Griffith looks for elegant ways to make real things, from low-cost eyeglasses to a kite that tows boats. His latest projects include open-source inventions and elegant new ways to generate power.

talkTitle: Everyday inventions

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Joshua Prince-Ramus is best known as architect of the Seattle Central Library, already being hailed as a masterpiece of contemporary culture. Prince-Ramus was the founding partner of OMA New York—the American affiliate of the Office for Metropolitan Architecture (OMA) in the Netherlands—and served as its Principal until he renamed the firm REX in 2006.

talkTitle: Behind the design of Seattle's library

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Renowned for album covers, posters and his recent book of life lessons, designer Stefan Sagmeister invariably has a slightly different way of looking at things.

talkTitle: Happiness by design

speakerInfo.speakerBio: 2006 TED Prize winner Cameron Sinclair is co-founder of Architecture for Humanity, a nonprofit that seeks architecture solutions to global crises -- and acts as a conduit between the design community and the world's humanitarian needs.

talkTitle: My wish: A call for open-source architecture

speakerInfo.speakerBio: TED Prize winner Jehane Noujaim is a gutsy filmmaker whose astonishing documentaries reveal the triumphs and hardships of courageous individuals.

talkTitle: My wish: A global day of film

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Robert Fischell invented the rechargeable pacemaker, the implantable insulin pump, and devices that warn of epileptic seizures and heart attacks. Yet it's not just his inventive genius that makes him fascinating, but his determination to make the world a better place.

talkTitle: My wish: Three unusual medical inventions

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Bono, the lead singer of U2, uses his celebrity to fight for social justice worldwide: to end hunger, poverty and disease, especially in Africa. His nonprofit ONE raises awareness via media, policy and calls to action.

talkTitle: My wish: Three actions for Africa

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Anna Deavere Smith's ground-breaking solo shows blur the lines between theater and journalism, using text from real-life encounters to create gripping portraits.

talkTitle: Four American characters

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Danish political scientist Bjorn Lomborg heads the Copenhagen Consensus, which has prioritized the world's greatest problems -- global warming, world poverty, disease -- based on how effective our solutions might be. It's a thought-provoking, even provocative list.

talkTitle: Global priorities bigger than climate change

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A researcher at the London think tank Demos, Charles Leadbeater was early to notice the rise of "amateur innovation" -- great ideas from outside the traditional walls, from people who suddenly have the tools to collaborate, innovate and make their expertise known.

talkTitle: The era of open innovation

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Eve Ensler created the ground-breaking "Vagina Monologues," whose success propelled her to found V-Day -- a movement to end violence against women and girls everywhere.

talkTitle: Happiness in body and soul

speakerInfo.speakerBio: After years of research on touch-driven computer displays, Jeff Han has created a simple, multi-touch, multi-user screen interface that just might herald the end of the point-and-click era.

talkTitle: The radical promise of the multi-touch interface

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Creativity expert Sir Ken Robinson challenges the way we're educating our children. He champions a radical rethink of our school systems, to cultivate creativity and acknowledge multiple types of intelligence.

talkTitle: Do schools kill creativity?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence, Wade Davis has been described as “a rare combination of scientist, scholar, poet and passionate defender of all of life’s diversity.”

talkTitle: Dreams from endangered cultures

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A self-described average guy who found success doing what he loved, Richard St. John spent more than a decade researching the lessons of success -- and distilling them into 8 words, 3 minutes and one successful book.

talkTitle: 8 secrets of success

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Pastor Rick Warren is the author of The Purpose-Driven Life, which has sold more than 30 million copies worldwide. His has become an immensely influential voice seeking to apply the values of his faith to issues such as global poverty, HIV/AIDS and injustice.

talkTitle: A life of purpose

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In his book In Praise of Slowness, Carl Honoré dissects our speed-obsessed society and celebrates those who have gotten in touch with their "inner tortoise."

talkTitle: In praise of slowness

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Alex Steffen explores our planet's future, telling powerful, inspiring stories about the hard choices facing humanity ... and our opportunity to create a much better tomorrow.

talkTitle: The route to a sustainable future

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Sasa Vucinic's Media Development Loan Fund applies venture-capital principles to create a sustainable free press in developing nations and countries emerging from repressive regimes.

talkTitle: Why we should invest in a free press

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Susan Savage-Rumbaugh has made startling breakthroughs in her lifelong work with chimpanzees and bonobos, showing the animals to be adept in picking up language and other "intelligent" behaviors.

talkTitle: The gentle genius of bonobos

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Biologist Sheila Patek is addicted to speed -- animal speed. She's measured the fastest animal movements in the world, made by snail-smashing mantis shrimp and the snapping mandibles of trap-jaw ants.

talkTitle: The shrimp with a kick!

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Al Seckel explored how eye tricks can reveal the way the brain processes visual information -- or fails to do so. Among his other accomplishments: He co-created the Darwin Fish.

talkTitle: Visual illusions that show how we (mis)think

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Iqbal Quadir is an advocate of business as a humanitarian tool. With GrameenPhone, he brought the first commercial telecom services to poor areas of Bangladesh. His latest project will help rural entrepreneurs build power plants.

talkTitle: How mobile phones can fight poverty

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Juan Enriquez thinks and writes about the profound changes that genomics and other life sciences will bring in business, technology, politics and society.

talkTitle: The life code that will reshape the future

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Biologist E.O. Wilson explores the world of ants and other tiny creatures, and writes movingly about the way all creatures great and small are interdependent.

talkTitle: My wish: Build the Encyclopedia of Life

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Photojournalist James Nachtwey is considered by many to be the greatest war photographer of recent decades. He has covered conflicts and major social issues in more than 30 countries.

talkTitle: My wish: Let my photographs bear witness

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Through his William J. Clinton Foundation, former US President Bill Clinton has become a vital and innovative force for world change. He works in four critical areas: health, economic empowerment, citizen service, and reconciliation.

talkTitle: My wish: Rebuilding Rwanda

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Julia Sweeney creates comedic works that tackle deep issues: cancer, family, faith.

talkTitle: Letting go of God

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ze Frank rose to fame on a viral video -- in 2001! He has been making online comedy, web toys and massively shared experiences (like the addictive Young Me Now Me) ever since.

talkTitle: Nerdcore comedy

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In 2004, Ben Saunders became the youngest person ever to ski solo to the North Pole. In 2013, he set out on another record-breaking expedition, this time to retrace Captain Scott’s ill-fated journey to the South Pole on foot.

talkTitle: Why did I ski to the North Pole?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In Hans Rosling’s hands, data sings. Global trends in health and economics come to vivid life. And the big picture of global development—with some surprisingly good news—snaps into sharp focus.

talkTitle: The best stats you've ever seen

speakerInfo.speakerTitle: Life coach; expert in leadership psychology
speakerInfo.speakerBio: Tony Robbins makes it his business to know why we do the things we do. The pioneering life coach has spoken to millions of people through his best-selling books and three-day seminars.

talkTitle: Why we do what we do

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jill Sobule isn't just another singer-songwriter with catchy tunes and smart lyrics, she's one of the more insightful satirists of our age. Each of her fanciful songs captures an issue or irony, an emotion or epiphany that helps us understand what it's like to live now.

talkTitle: Global warming's theme song, "Manhattan in January"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Dan Dennett argues that human consciousness and free will are the result of physical processes.

talkTitle: The illusion of consciousness

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Percussionist and composer Dame Evelyn Glennie lost nearly all of her hearing by age 12. Rather than isolating her, it has given her a unique connection to her music.

talkTitle: How to truly listen

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Architect William McDonough believes green design can prevent environmental disaster and drive economic growth. He champions “cradle to cradle” design, which considers a product's full life cycle -- from creation with sustainable materials to a recycled afterlife.

talkTitle: Cradle to cradle design

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As founder and CEO of Amazon.com, Jeff Bezos defined online shopping and rewrote the rules of commerce, ushering in a new era in business. Time magazine named him Man of the Year in 1999.

talkTitle: The electricity metaphor for the web's future

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In her warm, glorious voice, Eddi Reader sings thoughtful songs about love, longing and introspection.

talkTitle: "Kiteflyer's Hill"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The Vicar of St David's Church, Exeter, in the UK, is unafraid to take on some of religion's tougher issues.

talkTitle: Why would God create a tsunami?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Oxford professor Richard Dawkins has helped steer evolutionary science into the 21st century, and his concept of the "meme" contextualized the spread of ideas in the information age. In recent years, his devastating critique of religion has made him a leading figure in the New Atheism.

talkTitle: Militant atheism

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Traditionally, Tom Rielly closes the TED Conference with a merciless 18-minute monologue, skewering all the speakers with his deadpan delivery, spot-on satire and boundary-less performance (complete with PowerPoint, pratfalls and partial nudity).

talkTitle: A comic sendup of TED2006

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Natalie MacMaster is a star of Cape Breton fiddling, a Canadian tradition with Scottish roots. Her energetic style and virtuoso talent has brought her star billing on the international folk circuit.

talkTitle: Cape Breton fiddling in reel time

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Sergey Brin is half of the team that founded Google.

talkTitle: The genesis of Google

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Singer-songwriter Stew spins improvisatory songs drawn from his seemingly endless stable of stories and ideas. His musical Passing Strange won a Tony for Best Book in 2008.

talkTitle: "Black Men Ski"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Since the counterculture '60s, Stewart Brand has been creating our internet-worked world. Now, with biotech accelerating four times faster than digital technology, Stewart Brand has a bold new plan ...

talkTitle: What squatter cities can teach us

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Tierney Thys is a marine biologist and science educator. She studies the behavior of the Mola mola, or giant ocean sunfish -- and works with other scientists to make films that share the wonders they see.

talkTitle: Swim with the giant sunfish

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala is a respected global economist.

talkTitle: Want to help Africa? Do business here

speakerInfo.speakerBio: John Doerr is an engineer, a venture capitalist and the chair of Kleiner Perkins.

talkTitle: Salvation (and profit) in greentech

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Blaise Agüera y Arcas works on machine learning at Google. Previously a Distinguished Engineer at Microsoft, he has worked on augmented reality, mapping, wearable computing and natural user interfaces.

talkTitle: How PhotoSynth can connect the world's images

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Anand Agarawala's job: to imagine and build the computers you'll use in 20 years.

talkTitle: Rethink the desktop with BumpTop

speakerInfo.speakerTitle: Explorer, inventor and outer space dreamer
speakerInfo.speakerBio: Engineer and daredevil caver Bill Stone pushes the frontier -- through flooded tunnels, the remotest depths of the Earth and the limits of human endurance.

talkTitle: I'm going to the moon. Who's with me?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In the fight against disease, defect and injury, Alan Russell has a novel argument: Why not engineer new tissue and organs to replace sick ones?

talkTitle: The potential of regenerative medicine

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Artist and computer scientist Jonathan Harris makes online art that captures the world's expression -- and gives us a glimpse of the soul of the Internet.

talkTitle: The Web's secret stories

speakerInfo.speakerBio: By studying how ant colonies work without any one leader, Deborah Gordon has identified striking similarities in how ant colonies, brains, cells and computer networks regulate themselves.

talkTitle: The emergent genius of ant colonies

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Will Wright invented a genre of computer game that involves neither winning nor shooting, yet has generated colossal hits. Among them: SimCity (which earned its publisher $230 million), The Sims, and Spore.

talkTitle: Spore, birth of a game

speakerInfo.speakerBio: David Bolinsky and his team illustrate scientific and medical concepts with high-drama animation. You've never seen the life of a cell quite like this.

talkTitle: Visualizing the wonder of a living cell

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Performance artist and storyteller Rives has been called "the first 2.0 poet," using images, video and technology to bring his words to life.

talkTitle: The  4 a.m. mystery

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Allison Hunt has worked in advertising and marketing for 20 years, developing human insight and persuasion into an art for her clients. Six years after getting an artificial hip, she decided to try something new.

talkTitle: How to get (a new) hip

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Economist George Ayittey sees Africa's future as a fight between Hippos -- complacent, greedy bureaucrats wallowing in the muck -- and Cheetahs, the fast-moving, entrepreneurial leaders and citizens who will rebuild Africa.

talkTitle: Africa's cheetahs versus hippos

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala is a respected global economist.

talkTitle: Aid versus trade

speakerInfo.speakerBio: To power his family's home, young William Kamkwamba built an electricity-producing windmill from spare parts and scrap -- starting him on a journey detailed in the book and film "The Boy Who Harnessed the Wind."

talkTitle: How I built a windmill

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As leading advocate for Western Investment into Africa, BCG's Euvin Naidoo works with leading corporations and governments to strengthen trans-Atlantic economic ties.

talkTitle: Why invest in Africa

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Imprisoned three times by the Nigerian government, Chris Abani turned his experience into poems that Harold Pinter called "the most naked, harrowing expression of prison life and political torture imaginable." His novels include GraceLand (2004) and The Virgin of Flames (2007).

talkTitle: Telling stories from Africa

speakerInfo.speakerBio: After working at Microsoft for almost a decade, Patrick Awuah returned home to Ghana and cofounded Ashesi University, a small liberal arts college that aims to educate Africa's next generation of leaders. Its first class of students graduated in 2006.

talkTitle: How to educate leaders? Liberal arts

speakerInfo.speakerTitle: Investor and advocate for moral leadership
speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jacqueline Novogratz works to enable human flourishing. Her organization, Acumen, invests in people, companies and ideas that see capital and networks as means, not ends, to solving the toughest issues of poverty.

talkTitle: Patient capitalism

speakerInfo.speakerBio: South African singer-songwriter Vusi Mahlasela was a crucial artistic voice during the fight against apartheid, and now in the new modern-day nation. Blending traditional African music with soul and blues, his music showcases powerful vocals and poetic lyrics.

talkTitle: "Thula Mama"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Journalist Andrew Mwenda has spent his career fighting for free speech and economic empowerment throughout Africa. He argues that aid makes objects of the poor -- they become passive recipients of charity rather than active participants in their own economic betterment.

talkTitle: Aid for Africa? No thanks.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As the co-founder of Reverb Technologies, the maker of the online dictionary Wordnik, Erin McKean is reshaping how we interact with language itself.

talkTitle: The joy of lexicography

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Theo Jansen is a Dutch artist who builds walking kinetic sculptures that he calls a new form of life. His "Strandbeests" walk the coastline of Holland, feeding on wind and fleeing from water.

talkTitle: My creations, a new form of life

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Steven Pinker is a professor of cognitive science (the study of the human mind) who writes about language, mind and human nature.

talkTitle: The surprising decline in violence

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Hod Lipson works at the intersection of engineering and biology, studying robots and the way they "behave" and evolve. His work has exciting implications for design and manufacturing -- and serves as a window to understand our own behavior and evolution.

talkTitle: Building "self-aware" robots

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jeff Skoll was the first president of eBay; he used his dot-com fortune to found the film house Participant Productions, making movies to inspire social change, including Syriana; Good Night, and Good Luck; Murderball; An Inconvenient Truth ...

talkTitle: My journey into movies that matter

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The director of the award-winning documentary The War Tapes, Deborah Scranton is committed to using new technology to give people power to tell their own stories.

talkTitle: An Iraq war movie crowd-sourced from soldiers

speakerInfo.speakerBio: John Maeda, the former president of the Rhode Island School of Design, is dedicated to linking design and technology. Through the software tools, web pages and books he creates, he spreads his philosophy of elegant simplicity.

talkTitle: Designing for simplicity

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As the leader of the Imaging Team on the Cassini mission to Saturn, Carolyn Porco interprets and shares the pictures coming back from this fascinating planet, its rings and its moons.

talkTitle: This is Saturn

speakerInfo.speakerBio: 2013 "America's Got Talent" winner Kenichi Ebina blends hip-hop, martial arts, modern dance, magic and a blast of pop culture in his mesmerizing performances.

talkTitle: My magic moves

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Richard Branson bootstrapped his way from record-shop owner to head of the Virgin empire. Now he's focusing his boundless energy on saving our environment.

talkTitle: Life at 30,000 feet

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Maira Kalman's wise, witty drawings have appeared on numberless New Yorker covers, in a dozen children's books, and throughout the pages of the Elements of Style. Her latest book, The Principles of Uncertainty, is the result of a year-long illustrated blog she kept for the New York Times.

talkTitle: The illustrated woman

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Paul Rothemund folds DNA into shapes and patterns. Which is a simple enough thing to say, but the process he has developed has vast implications for computing and manufacturing -- allowing us to create things we can now only dream of.

talkTitle: Playing with DNA that self-assembles

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Neurologist V.S. Ramachandran looks deep into the brain’s most basic mechanisms. By working with those who have very specific mental disabilities caused by brain injury or stroke, he can map functions of the mind to physical structures of the brain.

talkTitle: 3 clues to understanding your brain

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Lawrence Lessig has already transformed intellectual-property law with his Creative Commons innovation. Now he's focused on an even bigger problem: The US' broken political system.

talkTitle: Laws that choke creativity

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Guitarist and singer Raul Midon blends flamenco, jazz and R&B to create a category-defying sound. His life story is as inspiring as his musical vision.

talkTitle: "Tembererana"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Sometimes called the "happiest man in the world," Matthieu Ricard is a Buddhist monk, author and photographer.

talkTitle: The habits of happiness

speakerInfo.speakerBio: David Keith studies our climate, and the many ideas we've come up with to fix it. A wildly original thinker, he challenges us to look at climate solutions that may seem daring, sometimes even shocking.

talkTitle: A critical look at geoengineering against climate change

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Juan Enriquez thinks and writes about the profound changes that genomics and other life sciences will bring in business, technology, politics and society.

talkTitle: Using biology to rethink the energy challenge

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Murray Gell-Mann brings visibility to a crucial aspect of our existence that we can't actually see: elemental particles. He won the Nobel Prize in Physics for introducing quarks, one of two fundamental ingredients for all matter in the universe.

talkTitle: Beauty, truth and ... physics?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Robert Full studies cockroach legs and gecko feet. His research is helping build tomorrow's robots, based on evolution's ancient engineering.

talkTitle: The sticky wonder of gecko feet

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Using daring displays of algorithmic trickery, lightning calculator and number wizard Arthur Benjamin mesmerizes audiences with mathematical mystery and beauty.

talkTitle: A performance of "Mathemagic"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Investor Yossi Vardi is godfather to more than 40 startups, mostly in the jumping Israeli high-tech sector. He's a legendary community-builder, connector and prankster.

talkTitle: We're worried about local warming ... in your lap

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Isabel Allende writes stories of passion. Her novels and memoirs, including The House of the Spirits and Eva Luna, tell the stories of women and men who live with passionate commitment -- to love, to their world, to an ideal.

talkTitle: Tales of passion

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Writer, director and producer J.J. Abrams makes smart, addictive dramas like TV's Lost, and films like Cloverfield and the new Star Trek.

talkTitle: The mystery box

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Paola Antonelli is on a mission to introduce -- and explain -- design to the world. With her shows at New York's Museum of Modern Art, she celebrates design's presence in every part of life.

talkTitle: Treat design as art

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As a Pittsburgh youth besieged by racism in the crumbling remains of the steel economy, Bill Strickland should have been one of the Rust Belt's casualties. Instead, he discovered the potter's wheel, and the transforming power of fountains, irrepressible dreams, and the slide show.

talkTitle: Rebuilding a neighborhood with beauty, dignity, hope

speakerInfo.speakerBio: After a long career in journalism and publishing, Chris Anderson became the curator of the TED Conference in 2002 and has developed it as a platform for identifying and disseminating ideas worth spreading.

talkTitle: TED's nonprofit transition

speakerInfo.speakerBio: With Zipcar, Robin Chase introduced car-crazy America to the concept of non-ownership. Now she's flipping that model with Buzzcar, which lets you rent your own auto to your neighbors.

talkTitle: The idea behind Zipcar (and what comes next)

speakerInfo.speakerBio: David Macaulay gets under the skins of skyscrapers, mosques, pyramids, subways, and a host of other ancient and modern marvels. His lavish and micro-detailed renderings expose the world's secret engineering to dazzled readers of all ages.

talkTitle: An illustrated journey through Rome

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Writer, artist and designer, theorist and community builder, Howard Rheingold is one of the driving minds behind our net-enabled, open, collaborative life.

talkTitle: The new power of collaboration

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Eve Ensler created the ground-breaking "Vagina Monologues," whose success propelled her to found V-Day -- a movement to end violence against women and girls everywhere.

talkTitle: What security means to me

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Pamelia Kurstin excavates a dusty artifact from the prehistoric strata of electronic music -- and demonstrates how to squeeze soul from an instrument you can't even touch.

talkTitle: The untouchable music of the theremin

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In telling stories of technologies and the individuals who created them, George Dyson takes a clear-eyed view of our scientific past -- while illuminating what lies ahead.

talkTitle: The story of Project Orion

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jill Sobule isn't just another singer-songwriter with catchy tunes and smart lyrics, she's one of the more insightful satirists of our age. Each of her fanciful songs captures an issue or irony, an emotion or epiphany that helps us understand what it's like to live now.

talkTitle: The Jill and Julia Show

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Curtis Wong is manager of Next Media Research for Microsoft, whose focus "spans the linear and interactive media spectrum from television, broadband and gaming to emerging media forms." He's a leader on the WorldWide Telescope project.

talkTitle: A preview of the WorldWide Telescope

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Venture capitalist Steve Jurvetson (he brought you Hotmail) is one of the most influential funders and thinkers in Silicon Valley. He's also an enthusiastic hobbyist, blogger and Flickr-er.

talkTitle: Model rocketry

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In 2001, Craig Venter made headlines for sequencing the human genome. In 2003, he started mapping the ocean's biodiversity. And now he's created the first synthetic lifeforms -- microorganisms that can produce alternative fuels.

talkTitle: On the verge of creating synthetic life

speakerInfo.speakerBio: One of the true luminaries of personal computing, Alan Kay conceived of laptops and graphical interfaces years before they were realized. At XeroxPARC, Apple, HP and Disney, he has developed tools for improving the mind.

talkTitle: A powerful idea about ideas

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A living legend, Frank Gehry has forged his own language of architecture, creating astonishing buildings all over the world, such as the Guggenheim in Bilbao, the Walt Disney Concert Hall in LA, and Manhattan's new IAC building.

talkTitle: My days as a young rebel

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Writing is only his day job: Dave Eggers moonlights as a publisher, philanthropist and advocate for students and teachers.

talkTitle: My wish: Once Upon a School

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Karen Armstrong -- winner of the 2008 TED Prize -- is a provocative, original thinker on the role of religion in the modern world.

talkTitle: My wish: The Charter for Compassion

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Siegfried Woldhek knows faces -- he's drawn more than 1,100 of them. Using sophisticated image analysis and his own skills as an artist, he's come up with a fascinating discovery about Leonardo Da Vinci.

talkTitle: The search for the true face of Leonardo

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Christopher deCharms is working on a way to use fMRI scans to show brain activity -- in real time.

talkTitle: A look inside the brain in real time

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Astronomer Clifford Stoll helped to capture a notorious KGB hacker back in the infancy of the Internet. His agile mind continues to lead him down new paths -- from education and techno-skepticism to the making of zero-volume bottles.

talkTitle: The call to learn

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jakob Trollback is a pioneering designer, whose work in video and motion graphics has helped define the industry -- always pushing the edges of technology and entertainment through design.

talkTitle: A new kind of music video

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Stephen Hawking's scientific investigations have shed light on the origins of the cosmos, the nature of time and the ultimate fate of the universe. His bestselling books for a general audience have given an appreciation of physics to millions.

talkTitle: Questioning the universe

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Researcher Johnny Lee became a YouTube star with his demo of Wii Remote hacks -- bending the low-cost game piece to power an interactive whiteboard, a multitouch surface, a head-mounted display ...

talkTitle: Free or cheap Wii Remote hacks

speakerInfo.speakerBio: At MIT's Media Lab, Tod Machover creates boundary-breaking new music, often using new instruments and music technologies he has invented.

talkTitle: Inventing instruments that unlock new music

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Yochai Benkler has been called "the leading intellectual of the information age." He proposes that volunteer-based projects such as Wikipedia and Linux are the next stage of human organization and economic production.

talkTitle: The new open-source economics

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As the CEO of Public Radio International, Alisa Miller works to bring the most significant news stories to millions  -- empowering Americans with the knowledge to make choices in an interconnected world.

talkTitle: How the news distorts our worldview

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Amy Tan is the author of such beloved books as The Joy Luck Club, The Kitchen God's Wife and The Hundred Secret Senses.

talkTitle: Where does creativity hide?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Brian Greene is perhaps the best-known proponent of superstring theory, the idea that minuscule strands of energy vibrating in a higher dimensional space-time create every particle and force in the universe.

talkTitle: Making sense of string theory

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Dean Ornish is a clinical professor at UCSF and founder of the Preventive Medicine Research Institute. He's a leading expert on fighting illness -- particularly heart disease with dietary and lifestyle changes.

talkTitle: Your genes are not your fate

speakerInfo.speakerBio: John Linnell and John Flansburgh are They Might Be Giants: multi-instrumental, tech-savvy and implacably prolific, they are the musicians of choice of geeks, tinkerers and curious kids of all ages.

talkTitle: Wake up! It's They Might Be Giants!

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Paul Stamets believes that mushrooms can save our lives, restore our ecosystems and transform other worlds.

talkTitle: 6 ways mushrooms can save the world

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Quite simply, Michael Moschen has revolutionized juggling, refining it into an art and a bit of a science. With a few flying balls and well-chosen props he will completely re-wire your notions of the physically possible.

talkTitle: Juggling as art ... and science

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Joshua Klein is a fervent hacker of all things, including wet, pulpy systems like animals and people and the way they behave.

talkTitle: A thought experiment on the intelligence of crows

speakerInfo.speakerBio: On more than 120 deep-sea expeditions, Robert Ballard has made many major natural discoveries, such as the deep-sea vents. Oh, and he found the Titanic.

talkTitle: The astonishing hidden world of the deep ocean

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Yves Behar has produced some of the new millennium's most coveted objects, like the Leaf lamp, the Jawbone headset, and the XO laptop for One Laptop per Child.

talkTitle: Designing objects that tell stories

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Arthur Ganson's kinetic metal sculptures mix high art with gearhead humor. He's also the inventor of the kids' construction toy Toobers & Zots.

talkTitle: Moving sculpture

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Physician Seyi Oyesola co-developed the "Hospital in a Box" -- a pop-up, portable, solar-powered OR for off-grid medicine in Africa and elsewhere. But, he says, Africa needs more than new tools to heal itself.

talkTitle: A hospital tour in Nigeria

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Susan Blackmore studies memes -- those self-replicating "life forms" that spread themselves via human consciousness. We're now headed, she believes, toward a new form of meme, spread by the technology we've created.

talkTitle: Memes and "temes"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Paul Collier’s book The Bottom Billion shows what is happening to the poorest people in the world, and offers ideas for opening up opportunities to all.

talkTitle: The "bottom billion"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Nathan Myhrvold is a professional jack-of-all-trades. After leaving Microsoft in 1999, he's been a world barbecue champion, a wildlife photographer, a chef, a contributor to SETI, and a volcano explorer.

talkTitle: Archeology, animal photography, BBQ ...

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence, Wade Davis has been described as “a rare combination of scientist, scholar, poet and passionate defender of all of life’s diversity.”

talkTitle: The worldwide web of belief and ritual

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Clay Shirky argues that the history of the modern world could be rendered as the history of ways of arguing, where changes in media change what sort of arguments are possible -- with deep social and political implications.

talkTitle: Institutions vs. collaboration

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Murray Gell-Mann brings visibility to a crucial aspect of our existence that we can't actually see: elemental particles. He won the Nobel Prize in Physics for introducing quarks, one of two fundamental ingredients for all matter in the universe.

talkTitle: The ancestor of language

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In telling stories of technologies and the individuals who created them, George Dyson takes a clear-eyed view of our scientific past -- while illuminating what lies ahead.

talkTitle: The birth of the computer

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Chris Jordan runs the numbers on modern American life -- making large-format, long-zoom artwork from the most mindblowing data about our stuff.

talkTitle: Turning powerful stats into art

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Robert Full studies cockroach legs and gecko feet. His research is helping build tomorrow's robots, based on evolution's ancient engineering.

talkTitle: Robots inspired by cockroach ingenuity

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A leading interpreter of Mahler and Beethoven, Benjamin Zander is known for his charisma and unyielding energy -- and for his brilliant pre-concert talks.

talkTitle: The transformative power of classical music

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Nellie McKay sings, croons, raps, grooves and -- barks? -- to glowing critical acclaim.

talkTitle: "Clonie"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Nellie McKay sings, croons, raps, grooves and -- barks? -- to glowing critical acclaim.

talkTitle: "Mother of Pearl," "If I Had You"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Rick Smolan is the co-founder of the America 24/7 and Day in the Life photography series -- and a natural storyteller in many media. His latest books are America at Home and Blue Planet Run.

talkTitle: The story of a girl

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As a botanist at the Okapi Wildlife Reserve in the Congo basin, Corneille Ewango has faced down poachers and soldiers who threaten this delicate and vital ecosystem.

talkTitle: A hero of the Congo forest

speakerInfo.speakerBio: By coding computer simulations with biologically modeled nervous systems, Torsten Reil and his company NaturalMotion breathe life into the animated characters inhabiting the most eye-poppingly realistic games and movies around.

talkTitle: Animate characters by evolving them

speakerInfo.speakerBio: With Freeman Dyson's astonishing forecasts for the future, it's hard to tell where science ends and science fiction begins. But far from being a wild-eyed visionary, Dyson is a clear and sober thinker -- and one not afraid of controversy or heresy.

talkTitle: Let's look for life in the outer solar system

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Think of Keith Barry as a hacker of the human brain -- writing routines that exploit its bugs and loopholes, and offering a revealing look at the software between our ears.

talkTitle: Brain magic

speakerInfo.speakerBio: South African product designer Marisa Fick-Jordan works with Zulu wire artists to develop a sustainable, worldwide market for their bold and shimmering work.

talkTitle: The wonder of Zulu wire art

speakerInfo.speakerBio: With an outspoken approach to the problems of rebuilding cites and a fearless eye for design, Reed Kroloff is helping to change the urban landscape of cities from New York to New Orleans.

talkTitle: A tour of modern architecture

speakerInfo.speakerBio: There may be no one better to contemplate the meaning of cultural change than Kevin Kelly, whose life story reads like a treatise on the value and impacts of technology.

talkTitle: The next 5,000 days of the web

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Kwabena Boahen wants to understand how brains work -- and to build a computer that works like the brain by reverse-engineering the nervous system. His group at Stanford is developing Neurogrid, a hardware platform that will emulate the cortex’s inner workings.

talkTitle: A computer that works like the brain

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Robert Lang merges mathematics with aesthetics to fold elegant modern origami. His scientific approach helps him make folds once thought impossible -- and has secured his place as one of the first great Western masters of the art.

talkTitle: The math and magic of origami

speakerInfo.speakerBio: An engineer with Google (he helped build Google Earth), Bruno Bowden is also an enthusiastic folder of paper.

talkTitle: Watch me fold origami (blindfolded)

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As director of photography for National Geographic, David Griffin works with some of the most powerful photographs the world has ever seen.

talkTitle: How photography connects us

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Nellie McKay sings, croons, raps, grooves and -- barks? -- to glowing critical acclaim.

talkTitle: "The Dog Song"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Patricia Burchat studies the structure and distribution of dark matter and dark energy. These mysterious ingredients can't be measured in conventional ways, yet form a quarter of the mass of our universe.

talkTitle: Shedding light on dark matter

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Cards that fly all over the table, spill onto the floor, and disappear beneath a laser beam. Welcome to the chaotic and flabbergasting magical world of Lennart Green, grand master of close-up card trickery.

talkTitle: Close-up card magic with a twist

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Software entrepreneur John Q. Walker uses computers to bring piano legends back to life -- digitally reconstructing their performances from audio tracks and playing them on real instruments, live.

talkTitle: Great piano performances, recreated

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ory Okolloh maintains the blog Mzalendo, providing an unprecedented look at the doings of Kenya's parliament -- information once unavailable to Kenyan citizens.

talkTitle: How I became an activist

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Paul Rothemund folds DNA into shapes and patterns. Which is a simple enough thing to say, but the process he has developed has vast implications for computing and manufacturing -- allowing us to create things we can now only dream of.

talkTitle: DNA folding, in detail

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jonathan Drori commissioned the BBC's very first websites, one highlight in a long career devoted to online culture and educational media -- and understanding how we learn.

talkTitle: What we think we know

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Einstein, the African grey parrot, has a vocabulary of more than 200 words and sounds; she can perform nearly half on cue.

talkTitle: A talking, squawking parrot

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Dr. Irwin Redlener spends his days imagining the worst: He studies how humanity might survive natural or human-made disasters of unthinkable severity. He's been an outspoken critic of half-formed government recovery plans (especially after Katrina).

talkTitle: How to survive a nuclear attack

speakerInfo.speakerBio: On the heels of a long and bruising camel ride, Keith Bellows became fascinated with the "SUV of the sand," and with the many thorny aspects of their personalities (and mating habits) most of us would rather not dwell upon.

talkTitle: The camel's hump

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Rodney Brooks builds robots based on biological principles of movement and reasoning. The goal: a robot who can figure things out.

talkTitle: Robots will invade our lives

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Noah Feldman studies the intersection of religion, politics and law.

talkTitle: Politics and religion are technologies

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Photojournalist James Nachtwey is considered by many to be the greatest war photographer of recent decades. He has covered conflicts and major social issues in more than 30 countries.

talkTitle: Moving photos of extreme drug-resistant TB

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Dave Perry is the visionary game designer behind some of the most beloved titles of the past two decades -- Earthworm Jim, MDK, Messiah, and game adaptations of films such as Terminator and The Matrix.

talkTitle: Are games better than life?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Steven Berlin Johnson examines the intersection of science, technology and personal experience.

talkTitle: The Web as a city

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Doris Kearns Goodwin writes insightful books on the US Presidency (JFK, LBJ, FDR and Lincoln, so far), telling each president's personal story against the backdrop of history.

talkTitle: Lessons from past presidents

speakerInfo.speakerBio: James Burchfield is a human beatbox. Using only his mouth, tongue, throat and vocal cords, he performs heavy, layered, club-style jams that seem to come from real drum machines and lusciously scratched turntables.

talkTitle: Playing invisible turntables

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jared Diamond investigates why cultures prosper or decline -- and what we can learn by taking a broad look across many kinds of societies.

talkTitle: Why do societies collapse?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Physicist Garrett Lisi has proposed a new "theory of everything" -- a grand unified theory that explains all the elementary particles, as well as gravity.

talkTitle: An 8-dimensional model of the universe

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Paola Antonelli is on a mission to introduce -- and explain -- design to the world. With her shows at New York's Museum of Modern Art, she celebrates design's presence in every part of life.

talkTitle: Design and the Elastic Mind

speakerInfo.speakerBio: John Hodgman is a writer, humorist, geek celebrity, former professional literary agent and expert on all world knowledge. He was the bumbling PC in Apple's long-running "I'm a Mac; I'm a PC" ad campaign.

talkTitle: Aliens, love — where are they?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Virginia Postrel is a writer and cultural critic who examines the hidden economics of modern society, poking at the unexamined ideas behind the march of progress.

talkTitle: On glamour

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Paul MacCready, an aircraft designer and environmentalist, is a pioneer of human-powered flight, alternative energy for transportation, and environmentally responsible design.

talkTitle: Nature vs. humans

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Kristen Ashburn's photographs bring us face-to-face with real people in desperate circumstances. Taking us to the intimate spaces of her subjects -- the victims of war, disaster, epidemic -- she elicits the sublime sadness and resolve of human beings in suffering.

talkTitle: The face of AIDS in Africa

speakerInfo.speakerBio: James Surowiecki argues that people, when we act en masse, are smarter than we think. He's the author of The Wisdom of Crowds and writes about finance for the New Yorker.

talkTitle: The power and the danger of online crowds

speakerInfo.speakerBio: John Francis walks the Earth, carrying a message of careful, truly sustainable development and respect for our planet.

talkTitle: Walk the earth ... my 17-year vow of silence

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Tim Brown is the CEO of the "innovation and design" firm IDEO -- taking an approach to design that digs deeper than the surface.

talkTitle: Tales of creativity and play

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Biophysicist Luca Turin studies the science of smell. He's the author of Perfumes: The Guide, and the subject of Chandler Burr's 2003 book The Emperor of Scent. His next project: developing an artificial nose.

talkTitle: The science of scent

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Lee Smolin is a theoretical physicist, working mainly in the field of quantum gravity. He's a founding member of the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics in Canada, and the author of The Trouble With Physics.

talkTitle: Science and democracy

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Samantha Power studies US foreign policy, especially as it relates to war and human rights. Her books take on the world's worst problems: genocide, civil war and brutal dictatorships.

talkTitle: A complicated hero in the war on dictatorship

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi mixes high fashion and the mass market, with a line of haute couture and a line for Target. Plus a talk show, a cabaret act, a movie, a new book ...

talkTitle: Fashion and creativity

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Comedian and cabaret artist Ursus Wehrli is on a crusade to tidy up art.

talkTitle: Tidying up art

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Since the counterculture '60s, Stewart Brand has been creating our internet-worked world. Now, with biotech accelerating four times faster than digital technology, Stewart Brand has a bold new plan ...

talkTitle: The Long Now

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The co-founder of Sun Microsystems, Bill Joy has, in recent years, turned his attention to the biggest questions facing humanity: Where are we going? What could go wrong? What's the next great thing?

talkTitle: What I'm worried about, what I'm excited about

speakerInfo.speakerBio:
Andy Hobsbawm is the founder and CMO of Evrythng.com and the founder of
the website Do The Green Thing.

talkTitle: Do the green thing

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Richard Preston wrote The Hot Zone, a classic look at the Ebola virus and the scientists who fight it. His wide-ranging curiosity about science and people has led him to cover a dizzying list of topics, with a lapidary attention to detail and an ear for the human voice.

talkTitle: The mysterious lives of giant trees

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Philip Rosedale (avatar "Philip Linden") is founder of Second Life, an online 3D virtual world inhabited by millions. He's chair of Linden Labs, the company behind the digital society.

talkTitle: Life in Second Life

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Four-time Grammy Award-winning folk musician David Holt is a born troubadour. Behind his energizing musicianship (often featuring unusual instruments like "the paper bag") is a deep love of hidden Appalachian wisdom and storytelling that shines on every stage he takes.

talkTitle: The joyful tradition of mountain music

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Benjamin Wallace is a journalist and author of The Billionaire's Vinegar, the true story of the world's most expensive bottle of (possibly phony?) wine. He's been a contributor to GQ, Details, Salon and The Washington Post.

talkTitle: The price of happiness

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The founder of the MIT Media Lab, Nicholas Negroponte pushed the edge of the information revolution as an inventor, thinker and angel investor. He's the driving force behind One Laptop per Child, building computers for children in the developing world.

talkTitle: Taking OLPC to Colombia

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The possessor of the best byline in the New York Times, Jennifer 8. Lee reports on culture and city life. Her latest book is The Fortune Cookie Chronicles.

talkTitle: The hunt for General Tso

speakerInfo.speakerBio: John Maeda, the former president of the Rhode Island School of Design, is dedicated to linking design and technology. Through the software tools, web pages and books he creates, he spreads his philosophy of elegant simplicity.

talkTitle: My journey in design

speakerInfo.speakerBio: With a team of engineers, Paul Moller works on the Skycar, a combination car and jet, as well as the M200, a saucer-shaped hovering car. He also develops next-generation engines to power these and other amazing vehicles.

talkTitle: My dream of a flying car

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Greg Lynn is the head of Greg Lynn FORM, an architecture firm known for its boundary-breaking, biomorphic shapes and its embrace of digital tools for design and fabrication.

talkTitle: Organic algorithms in architecture

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Rob Forbes founded Design Within Reach, the furniture company that brought high design to the general public.

talkTitle: Ways of seeing

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Scott McCloud is author of Understanding Comics, a comic book about comics. He's an evangelist for comics as a valid literary form (as more than pulp and kids' stuff) and his admiring fans include a laundry list of superstar cartoonists.

talkTitle: The visual magic of comics

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Master breadmaker Peter Reinhart is also a teacher, author and theologian. Through his lectures and numerous cookbooks, he channels the science of baking into deep, spiritual lessons -- and dispels stale myths about the nature (and flavor) of good, wholesome bread.

talkTitle: The art and craft of bread

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A writer and veteran consultant to entrepreneurs and executives alike, Joseph Pine's books and workshops help businesses create what modern consumers really want: authentic experiences.

talkTitle: What consumers want

speakerInfo.speakerBio: David Carson is the "grunge typographer" whose magazine Ray Gun helped explode the possibilities of text on a page.

talkTitle: Design and discovery

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Barry Schuler's multimedia firm Medior built key interactive technologies for AOL, helping millions connect to the Internet through a simple, accessible interface. Now, through venture capital (and wine appreciation), he wants to do the same for genomics.

talkTitle: Genomics 101

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Peter D. Ward studies life on Earth -- where it came from, how it might end, and how utterly rare it might be.

talkTitle: A theory of Earth's mass extinctions

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A practicing surgeon for three decades, Sherwin Nuland witnessed life and death in every variety. Then he turned to writing, exploring what there is to people beyond just anatomy.

talkTitle: The extraordinary power of ordinary people

speakerInfo.speakerBio: If his career began and ended with "I [heart] N Y," Milton Glaser would still be a legend. But over his multi-decade career, his body of work is sprinkled with similarly iconic images and logos.

talkTitle: Using design to make ideas new

speakerInfo.speakerBio: David Merrill works on Siftables, tiny computer blocks that interact with each other to make networks (and music).

talkTitle: Toy tiles that talk to each other

speakerInfo.speakerBio: José Antonio Abreu founded El Sistema in 1975 to help Venezuelan kids learn to play musical instruments and be part of an orchestra. The TED Prize winner's bold idea has seeded hundreds of youth orchestras -- and many happy lives.

talkTitle: The El Sistema music revolution

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Sylvia Earle has been at the forefront of ocean exploration for more than four decades. The winner of the 2009 TED Prize, she's a tireless advocate for our oceans.

talkTitle: My wish: Protect our oceans

speakerInfo.speakerBio: SETI's Jill Tarter has devoted her career to hunting for signs of sentient beings elsewhere. Winner of the 2009 TED Prize, almost all aspects of her field have been affected by her work.

talkTitle: Join the SETI search

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ed Ulbrich works at the leading edge of computer-generated visuals. On a recent project, filmmakers, artists, and technologists have been working at a breakthrough point where reality and digitally created worlds collide.

talkTitle: How Benjamin Button got his face

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Charles Moore is founder of the Algalita Marine Research Foundation. He captains the foundation's research vessel, the Alguita, documenting the great expanses of plastic waste that now litter our oceans.

talkTitle: Seas of plastic

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ichthyologist Richard Pyle is a fish nerd. In his quest to discover and document new species of fish, he has also become a trailblazing exploratory diver and a pioneer of database technology.

talkTitle: A dive into the reef's Twilight Zone

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Miru Kim is a fearless explorer of abandoned and underground places. Her photography underscores the vulnerable nature of the human explorer in these no-woman's-lands.

talkTitle: My underground art explorations

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Evan Williams is the co-founder of Twitter, the addictive messaging service that connects the world 140 characters at a time.

talkTitle: The voices of Twitter users

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Brenda Laurel has been part of several major revolutions in the way humans use computers: virtual reality, interactive narratives and some fresh approaches to gaming.

talkTitle: Why not make video games for girls?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Called "the queen of canopy research," Nalini Nadkarni explores the rich, vital world found in the tops of trees. She communicates what she finds to non-scientists -- with the help of poets, preachers and prisoners.

talkTitle: Conserving the canopy

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As head of the MIT Media Lab's Fluid Interfaces Group, Pattie Maes researches the tools we use to work with information and connect with one another.

talkTitle: Meet the SixthSense interaction

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A record-breaker at the Paralympic Games in 1996, Aimee Mullins has built a career as a model, actor and advocate for women, sports and the next generation of prosthetics.

talkTitle: My 12 pairs of legs

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Stuart Brown's research shows play is not just joyful and energizing -- it's deeply involved with human development and intelligence. Through the National Institute for Play, he's working to better understand its significance.

talkTitle: Play is more than just fun

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web. He leads the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C), overseeing the Web's standards and development.

talkTitle: The next web

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Dan Dennett argues that human consciousness and free will are the result of physical processes.

talkTitle: Cute, sexy, sweet, funny

speakerInfo.speakerBio: With its air-filtering plants and sustainable architecture, Kamal Meattle's office park in New Delhi is a model of green business. Meattle himself is a longtime activist for cleaning up India's air.

talkTitle: How to grow fresh air

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Often called a social poet, C.K. Williams was fascinated by the characters of modern civilization and their interactions.

talkTitle: Poetry of youth and age

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Could good design save the newspaper -- at least for now? Jacek Utko thinks so -- and his lively, engaging designs for European papers prove that it works.

talkTitle: Can design save newspapers?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ueli Gegenschatz took flight just about every way a human can: paragliding, skydiving, BASE jumping (from the Eiffel Tower), and most breathtakingly: by donning a wingsuit and soaring.

talkTitle: Extreme wingsuit flying

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A consultant to the CIA and the Department of Defense, Bruce Bueno de Mesquita has built an intricate computer model that can predict the outcomes of international conflicts with bewildering accuracy.

talkTitle: A prediction for the future of Iran

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Bonnie Bassler studies how bacteria can communicate with one another, through chemical signals, to act as a unit. Her work could pave the way for new, more potent medicine.

talkTitle: How bacteria "talk"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Humorist, writer and trickster Emily Levine riffs on science and the human condition.

talkTitle: A theory of everything

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Renny Gleeson helps navigate brands through fresh concepts, such as viral marketing and social media, to find the pulse of the modern consumer.

talkTitle: Our antisocial phone tricks

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Shai Agassi wants to put you behind the wheel of an electric car -- but he doesn't want you to sacrifice convenience (or cash) to do it.

talkTitle: A new ecosystem for electric cars

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Composer JoAnn Kuchera-Morin is the director of the Center for Research in Electronic Art Technology (CREATE) at UC Santa Barbara.

talkTitle: Stunning data visualization in the AlloSphere

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Matthew Childs is an advertising lead at Razorfish. He is a lifelong rock climber and climbing guide.

talkTitle: 9 life lessons from rock climbing

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Design legend Niels Diffrient is the creator of the Freedom Chair, a radical rethink of the way we sit today. Throughout his career, he's been a pioneer of ergonomic design -- studying the human body (in all its shapes and sizes) and how to make it comfortable.

talkTitle: Rethinking the way we sit down

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Math whiz and baseball fan Nate Silver was mainly known for predicting outcomes in fantasy ballgames -- until his technique hit a home run calling the outcome of the 2008 election primaries.

talkTitle: Does racism affect how you vote?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Erik Hersman harnesses Africa’s boundless spirit of innovation by creating platforms to improve daily lives both inside and outside the continent.

talkTitle: Reporting crisis via texting

speakerInfo.speakerBio: With the hit economic blog MarginalRevolution.com, co-author Alex Tabarrok generates more hits than a summer hailstorm, and sheds light into the darkest corners of the dismal science.

talkTitle: How ideas trump crises

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Tony Award-winning monologist, UNICEF ambassador, firebrand and FCC-fighting poet -- Sarah Jones assumes as many roles offstage as on.

talkTitle: A one-woman global village

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Pulitzer winner Laurie Garrett studies global health and disease prevention. Her books include "The Coming Plague" and "Betrayal of Trust," about the crisis in global public health.

talkTitle: Lessons from the 1918 flu

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Physicist Brian Cox has two jobs: working with the Large Hadron Collider at CERN, and explaining big science to the general public. He's a professor at the University of Manchester.

talkTitle: What went wrong at the LHC

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Sean Gourley, trained as a physicist, has turned his scientific mind to analyzing data about a messier topic: modern war and conflict. He is a TED Fellow.

talkTitle: The mathematics of war

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Tom Shannon's mixed-material sculpture seems to levitate -- often it actually does -- thanks to powerful magnets and clever arrangements of suspension wire. He designed the TED Prize trophy.

talkTitle: Anti-gravity sculpture

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Nobel Laureate Al Gore focused the world’s attention on the global climate crisis. Now he’s showing us how we’re moving towards real solutions.

talkTitle: What comes after An Inconvenient Truth?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The group Naturally 7 practices vocal play -- the art of using the human voice to mimic instruments. It's as if a beatboxing troupe decided they could "-box" a whole orchestra: flute, horns, drums, guitar -- building a vocal wall of sound.

talkTitle: A full-band beatbox

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The dismal science of economics is not as firmly grounded in actual behavior as was once supposed. In "Predictably Irrational," Dan Ariely told us why.

talkTitle: Are we in control of our own decisions?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Death, the afterlife, and now sex -- Mary Roach tackles the most pondered and least understood conundrums that have baffled humans for centuries. (She's funny, too.)

talkTitle: 10 things you didn't know about orgasm

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As the leader of the Imaging Team on the Cassini mission to Saturn, Carolyn Porco interprets and shares the pictures coming back from this fascinating planet, its rings and its moons.

talkTitle: Could a Saturn moon harbor life?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Yves Behar has produced some of the new millennium's most coveted objects, like the Leaf lamp, the Jawbone headset, and the XO laptop for One Laptop per Child.

talkTitle: A supercharged motorcycle design

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jay Walker is fascinated by intellectual property in all its forms. His firm, Walker Digital, created Priceline and many other businesses that reframe old problems with new IT. In his private life, he's a bibliophile and collector on an epic scale.

talkTitle: The world's English mania

speakerInfo.speakerTitle: First Lady of the United States
speakerInfo.speakerBio: First Lady Michelle Obama, a lawyer and administrator, is an advocate for working parents and education for girls all around the world.

talkTitle: A passionate, personal case for education

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jonathan Drori commissioned the BBC's very first websites, one highlight in a long career devoted to online culture and educational media -- and understanding how we learn.

talkTitle: Why we're storing billions of seeds

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Kaki King combines jaw-dropping guitar work with dreamy, searching songwriting.

talkTitle: Playing "Pink Noise" on guitar

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Liz Coleman radically remade Bennington College in the mid-1990s, in pursuit of a new vision: higher education as a performing art.

talkTitle: A call to reinvent liberal arts education

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ray Kurzweil is an engineer who has radically advanced the fields of speech, text and audio technology. He's revered for his dizzying -- yet convincing -- writing on the advance of technology, the limits of biology and the future of the human species.

talkTitle: A university for the coming singularity

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Former hippie, former jailbird, former aficionado of crack cocaine, Felix Dennis built one of the most successful privately owned magazine empires in the world.

talkTitle: Odes to vice and consequences

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Pete Alcorn is the head of podcasting for Apple, and a veteran of the paper-publishing industry.

talkTitle: The world in 2200

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A self-described average guy who found success doing what he loved, Richard St. John spent more than a decade researching the lessons of success -- and distilling them into 8 words, 3 minutes and one successful book.

talkTitle: Success is a continuous journey

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Philip Zimbardo was the leader of the notorious 1971 Stanford Prison Experiment -- and an expert witness at Abu Ghraib. His book The Lucifer Effect explores the nature of evil; now, in his new work, he studies the nature of heroism.

talkTitle: The psychology of time

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In January 2009, Ray Zahab broke the record for fastest unsupported trek across Antarctica, to raise awareness and money for kids' environmental education. In 2006, he ran across the Sahara to raise awareness of water shortages. (He started running 5 years ago.)

talkTitle: My trek to the South Pole

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The founder of the Tinkering School, Gever Tulley likes to build things with kids.

talkTitle: Life lessons through tinkering

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Being a designer of breathtaking and sometimes confounding buildings seems almost a footnote to the amazing life of architect Daniel Libeskind.

talkTitle: 17 words of architectural inspiration

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Tom Wujec studies how we share and absorb information. He's an innovative practitioner of business visualization -- using design and technology to help groups solve problems and understand ideas. He is a Fellow at Autodesk.

talkTitle: 3 ways the brain creates meaning

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Sophal Ear leads research on post-conflict countries -- looking at the effectiveness of foreign aid and the challenge of development in places like his native land, Cambodia.

talkTitle: Escaping the Khmer Rouge

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The transparent simplicity and experiential nature of his work has built Olafur Eliasson's reputation as one of the world's most accessible creators of contemporary art.

talkTitle: Playing with space and light

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Daniel Kraft is a physician-scientist, inventor and innovator. He is faculty chair for the Medicine and Exponential Medicine program at Singularity University, exploring the impact and potential of rapidly developing technologies as applied to health and medicine.

talkTitle: A better way to harvest bone marrow

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Sloan Scholar, Fulbright Fellow, Professor Emeritus of Neuroscience, Jim Fallon looks at the way nature and nurture intermingle to wire up the human brain.

talkTitle: Exploring the mind of a killer

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Nina Jablonski is author of Skin: A Natural History, a close look at human skin’s many remarkable traits: its colors, its sweatiness, the fact that we decorate it.

talkTitle: Skin color is an illusion

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Britain's former prime minister Gordon Brown played a key role in shaping the G20 nations' response to the world's financial crisis, and was a powerful advocate for a coordinated global response to problems such as climate change, poverty and social justice.

talkTitle: Wiring a web for global good

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Through his witty and literate books -- and his new School of Life  -- Alain de Botton helps others find fulfillment in the everyday.

talkTitle: A kinder, gentler philosophy of success

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Half performance artist, half software engineer, Golan Levin manipulates the computer to create improvised soundscapes with dazzling corresponding visuals. He is at the forefront of defining new parameters for art.

talkTitle: Art that looks back at you

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Elaine Morgan, armed with an arsenal of television writing credits and feminist credentials, spent her life on a mission to prove humans evolved in water.

talkTitle: I believe we evolved from aquatic apes

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Willard Wigan sculpts figures small enough to fit on the head of a pin. To create these microscopic masterpieces, he works diligently through the stillest hours of the night, between his own heartbeats.

talkTitle: Hold your breath for micro-sculpture

speakerInfo.speakerBio: With cutting-edge nanotech, Michael Pritchard's Lifesaver water-purification bottle could revolutionize water-delivery systems in disaster-stricken areas around the globe.

talkTitle: How to make filthy water drinkable

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A self-proclaimed nature nerd, Janine Benyus' concept of biomimicry has galvanized scientists, architects, designers and engineers into exploring new ways in which nature's successes can inspire humanity.

talkTitle: Biomimicry in action

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Bidding adieu to his last "real job" as Al Gore's speechwriter, Dan Pink went freelance to spark a right-brain revolution in the career marketplace.

talkTitle: The puzzle of motivation

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As the CEO of MIT-inspired WiTricity, Eric Giler has a plan to beam electric power through the air to wirelessly power your laptop or recharge your car. You may never plug in again.

talkTitle: A demo of wireless electricity

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Biodiversity warrior Cary Fowler wants to save the world from agricultural collapse, one seed at a time.

talkTitle: One seed at a time, protecting the future of food
