speakerInfo.speakerBio: BCG's Yves Morieux researches how corporations can adapt to a modern and complex business landscape.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with BCG San Francisco.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: By day he's a graphic designer, and by night Joe Kowan is a quirky folk singer-songwriter.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with State Street Boston.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: When McKenna Pope was 13 she petitioned Hasbro to market its Easy-Bake Oven to boys as well as girls, and to make it available in gender-neutral colors. It worked.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Maya Penn makes eco-friendly clothes and accessories, which she sells on a site she built -- and gives away a percent of the profits.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A part of the Bangalore-based artist duo Pors & Rao, TED Senior Fellow Aparna Rao works with electro-mechanical systems and interactive installations.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Alex Wissner-Gross applies science and engineering principles to big (and diverse) questions, like: "What is the equation for intelligence?" and "What's the best way to raise awareness about climate change?"

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Yann Dall'Aglio is a philosopher who thinks deeply about modern love.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Chris McKnett helps institutional investors put money toward sustainable and socially-forward assets.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with State Street Boston.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: People relying on synthetic speech use the voice they’re given, not their own. Rupal Patel created the vocaliD project to change that.

talkTitle: Synthetic voices, as unique as fingerprints

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A senior managing director and head of global macro strategy at State Street Global Markets, Michael Metcalfe provides high quality capital flow research.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with State Street Boston.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: BCG's Roselinde Torres studies what makes great leaders tick -- and figures out how to teach others the same skills.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with BCG San Francisco.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The co-author of "Sex at Dawn," Christopher Ryan explores the prehistoric roots of human sexuality.

talkTitle: Are we designed to be sexual omnivores?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ash Beckham approaches hard conversations from a place of compassion and empathy.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Catherine Bracy is the director of community organizing at Code for America.

talkTitle: Why good hackers make good citizens

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ajit Narayanan is the inventor of Avaz, an affordable, tablet-based communication device for people who are speech-impaired.

talkTitle: A word game to communicate in any language

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Siddharthan Chandran explores how to heal damage from degenerative disorders such as MS and motor neuron disease (ALS).

talkTitle: Can the damaged brain repair itself?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: At 17, Henry Lin won an Intel Foundation Young Scientist Award for his mathematical models of distant galaxy clusters.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Annette Heuser proposes critical reforms to loosen the iron grip of rating agencies on national credit scores.

talkTitle: The 3 agencies with the power to make or break economies

speakerInfo.speakerBio: BCG's Philip Evans has a bold prediction for the future of business strategy -- and it starts with Big Data.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with BCG San Francisco.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Christopher Soghoian researches and exposes the high-tech surveillance tools that governments use to spy on their own citizens, and he is a champion of digital privacy rights.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: TED Fellow Manu Prakash is on a mission to bring radical new technology to global health.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Gabe Barcia-Colombo creates madcap art inspired both by Renaissance era curiosity cabinets and the modern-day digital chronicling of everyday life. Think: miniature people projected in objects and a DNA Vending Machine.

talkTitle: My DNA vending machine

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Anne-Marie Slaughter has exploded the conversation around women’s work-life balance.

talkTitle: Can we all "have it all"?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The publisher and editor of Stuff magazine, Toby Shapshak is a South African writer focusing on innovation — and the role it plays in Africa.

talkTitle: You don't need an app for that

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Carin Bondar is an expert on the sexual life of animals -- and loves to tell their wild sex stories.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Daniel Reisel searches for the psychological and physical roots of human morality.

talkTitle: The neuroscience of restorative justice

speakerInfo.speakerBio: At Boston's Children Hospital, endocrinologist Norman Spack treats transgender teens to delay the effects of puberty.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Rebecca Newberger Goldstein writes novels and nonfiction that explore questions of philosophy, morality and being.

talkTitle: The long reach of reason

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Charmian Gooch is the 2014 TED Prize winner. At Global Witness, she exposes how a global architecture of corruption is woven into the extraction and exploitation of natural resources.

talkTitle: My wish: To launch a new era of openness in business

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Tweeting (and covering Bowie) from the International Space Station last year, Colonel Chris Hadfield reminded the world how much we love space.

talkTitle: What I learned from going blind in space

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Richard Ledgett is deputy director and senior civilian leader of the National Security Agency. He acts as the agency’s chief operating officer, responsible for guiding and directing studies, operations and policy.

talkTitle: The NSA responds to Edward Snowden's TED Talk

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Larry Page is the CEO and cofounder of Google, making him one of the ruling minds of the web.

talkTitle: Where's Google going next?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Despite an attack on his daughter Malala in 2012, Ziauddin Yousafzai continues his fight to educate children in the developing world.

talkTitle: My daughter, Malala

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ed Yong blogs with a mission: to ignite excitement for science in everyone, regardless of their education or background.

talkTitle: Zombie roaches and other parasite tales

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Once known for entertaining millions by creating special effects for Hollywood, theme parks and Broadway, Applied Minds cofounder Bran Ferren now solves impossible tech challenges with previously unimaginable inventions.

talkTitle: To create for the ages, let's combine art and engineering

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As the director of the Human-Computer Interaction Lab at the University of Maryland, Jennifer Golbeck studies how people use social media -- and thinks about ways to improve their interactions.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Del Harvey works to define policy and to ensure user safety and security in the challenging realm of modern social media.

talkTitle: Protecting Twitter users (sometimes from themselves)

speakerInfo.speakerBio: At MIT, Hugh Herr builds prosthetic knees, legs and ankles that fuse biomechanics with microprocessors to restore (and perhaps enhance) normal gait, balance and speed.

talkTitle: The new bionics that let us run, climb and dance

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Geena Rocero is a professional model for fashion and beauty companies around the world. And she uses her platform to share a powerful story.

talkTitle: Why I must come out

speakerInfo.speakerBio: With TED-Ed communicator Emilie Soffe as the leading lady, the TED staff puts on a show.

talkTitle: It's TED, the Musical

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Allan Adams is a theoretical physicist working at the intersection of fluid dynamics, quantum field theory and string theory.

talkTitle: The discovery that could rewrite physics

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Melinda French Gates is co-chair of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, where she puts into practice the idea that every life has equal value.

talkTitle: Why giving away our wealth has been the most satisfying thing we've done

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Christopher Emdin is a science advocate who uses hip-hop to make better teachers.

talkTitle: Teach teachers how to create magic

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Even the most advanced prosthetic isn't useful if it's hard to wear. This observation guides TED Fellow David Sengeh's work at the Biomechatronics group in the MIT Media Lab.

talkTitle: The sore problem of prosthetic limbs

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Writer and thinker David Brooks has covered business, crime and politics over a long career in journalism.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In her new book "All Joy and No Fun," Jennifer Senior explores how children reshape their parents' lives -- for better and worse.

talkTitle: For parents, happiness is a very high bar

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Using innovative orbiting instruments, aerospace engineer Jeremy Kasdin hunts for the universe’s most elusive objects — potentially habitable worlds.

talkTitle: The flower-shaped starshade that might help us detect Earth-like planets

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Even if you don’t recognize his name, chances are you’ve seen Matthew Carter’s work -- his type designs include some of the world’s most familiar digital typefaces.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In a lab near Vancouver, Michel Laberge and his team at General Fusion are building a prototype fusion reactor that mimics the processes of the sun to produce cheap, clean and abundant energy.

talkTitle: How synchronized hammer strikes could generate nuclear fusion

speakerInfo.speakerBio: At Planet Labs, Will Marshall is helping share near-real-time images of our planet, from a constellation of earth-observing satellites.

talkTitle: Tiny satellites show us the Earth as it changes in near-real-time

speakerInfo.speakerBio: James Patten, a TED Fellow, imagines new ways for us to play with computers.

talkTitle: The best computer interface? Maybe ... your hands

speakerInfo.speakerBio: At the Simons Foundation, Wendy Chung is working to characterize behavior, brain structure and function in people with genetic variations that may relate to autism.

talkTitle: Autism — what we know (and what we don't know yet)

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Andrew Bastawrous studies eye health -- and builds accessible new tools to bring eye health to more people. He is a 2014 TED Fellow.

talkTitle: Get your next eye exam on a smartphone

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Tony Award-winning monologist, UNICEF ambassador, firebrand and FCC-fighting poet -- Sarah Jones assumes as many roles offstage as on.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Mellody Hobson is president of Ariel Investments, a value-driven money management firm -- and an advocate for financial literacy and investor education.

talkTitle: Color blind or color brave?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Marco Tempest is a cyber illusionist, combining magic and technology to produce astonishing illusions.

talkTitle: And for my next trick, a robot

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Randall Munroe sketches elegant and illuminating explanations of the weird science and math questions that keep geeks awake at night.

talkTitle: Comics that ask "what if?"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: His production credits range from Amy Winehouse to Paul McCartney -- ace DJ, musician and producer Mark Ronson has lived recent music history from the inside out.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: By studying how ant colonies work without any one leader, Deborah Gordon has identified striking similarities in how ant colonies, brains, cells and computer networks regulate themselves.

talkTitle: What ants teach us about the brain, cancer and the Internet

speakerInfo.speakerBio: William Black is a professor of economics and law at University of Missouri, Kansas City.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Simon Sinek explores how leaders can inspire cooperation, trust and change. He's the author of the classic "Start With Why"; his latest book is "Leaders Eat Last."

talkTitle: Why good leaders make you feel safe

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Performance artist and storyteller Rives has been called "the first 2.0 poet," using images, video and technology to bring his words to life.

talkTitle: The Museum of Four in the Morning

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Do humans have pheromones? Tristram Wyatt is on the case. A researcher at Oxford, Wyatt is interested in the evolution of pheromones throughout the animal kingdom.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jackie Savitz works to protect the world's oceans. A marine biologist, she is passionate that saving the seas will benefit us all.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Andrew Solomon writes about politics, culture and psychology.

talkTitle: How the worst moments in our lives make us who we are

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jon Mooallem is the author of "Wild Ones: A Sometimes Dismaying, Weirdly Reassuring Story About Looking at People Looking at Animals in America."

talkTitle: How the teddy bear taught us compassion

speakerInfo.speakerBio: He’s sold more than 100 million albums and earned 16 Grammy Awards, yet Sting continues to surprise. His fourteenth solo album, The Last Ship, features songs from his Broadway-bound musical of the same name.

talkTitle: How I started writing songs again

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Harvard psychologist Dan Gilbert says our beliefs about what will make us happy are often wrong -- a premise he supports with intriguing research, and explains in his accessible and unexpectedly funny book, Stumbling on Happiness.

talkTitle: The psychology of your future self

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In his influential poetry criticism, Stephen Burt links the contemporary with the classical, pinpoints new poetry movements, and promotes outstanding little-known poets.

talkTitle: Why people need poetry

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In her documentary films, Yoruba Richen unites African-American, feminist and LGBTQ voices in a renewed cry for civil rights for all.

talkTitle: What the gay rights movement learned from the civil rights movement

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Keren Elazari charts the transformation of hackers from cyberpunk protagonists to powerful hacktivists, lone rangers and digital robin hoods who are the unsung heroes of the digital frontier.

talkTitle: Hackers: the Internet's immune system

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Immersing himself in alternate lifestyles and long, hilarious experiments (usually with himself the guinea pig), writer AJ Jacobs tests the limits of behavior, customs, culture, knowledge -- and his wife's sense of humor.

talkTitle: The world's largest family reunion ... we're all invited!

speakerInfo.speakerBio: English professor Anne Curzan actually encourages her students to use slang in class. A language historian, she is fascinated by how people use words—and by how this changes.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ruth Chang asks why some choices are so hard — and what that means for the human condition.

talkTitle: How to make hard choices

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Groomed for terror, Zak Ebrahim chose a different life. The author of The Terrorist's Son, he hopes his story will inspire others to reject a path of violence.

talkTitle: I am the son of a terrorist. Here's how I chose peace.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: At 3D Systems, Avi Reichental is helping to imagine a future where 3D scanning-and-printing is an everyday act, and food, clothing, objects are routinely output at home.

talkTitle: What's next in 3D printing

speakerInfo.speakerBio: David Kwong creates illusions for films and TV, and makes verbal magic as a crossword puzzle maker for the New York Times.

talkTitle: Two nerdy obsessions meet — and it's magic

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jamila Lyiscott weaves words about language, education and the African Diaspora.

talkTitle: 3 ways to speak English

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Using literature as a lifeline, Shaka Senghor escaped a cycle of prison and desperation. Now his story kindles hope in those who have little.

talkTitle: Why your worst deeds don’t define you

speakerInfo.speakerBio: At Carnegie Mellon University, Lorrie Faith Cranor studies online privacy, usable security, phishing, spam and other research around keeping us safe online.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A two-term U.S. Poet Laureate, Billy Collins captures readers with his understated wit, profound insight -- and a sense of being "hospitable."

talkTitle: Two poems about what dogs think (probably)

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Both a musician and a computer scientist, Ge Wang turns ordinary MacBooks and iPhones into complex instruments.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Julian Treasure studies sound and advises businesses on how best to use it.

talkTitle: How to speak so that people want to listen

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Chris Domas is an embedded systems engineer and cybersecurity researcher.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: After 20 years working with the presidents and prime ministers of 54 countries, Simon Anholt has a plan to make the world work better.

talkTitle: Which country does the most good for the world?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Paul Bloom explores some of the most puzzling aspects of human nature, including pleasure, religion, and morality.

talkTitle: Can prejudice ever be a good thing?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The beloved Mr. Sulu from the original Star Trek, George Takei is an activist for human rights (and a master of Facebook memes).

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Joi Ito is the director of the MIT Media Lab.

talkTitle: Want to innovate? Become a "now-ist"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Karima Bennoune's new book introduces the world to people who speak out against fundamentalist terrorism.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The founder of the MIT Media Lab, Nicholas Negroponte pushed the edge of the information revolution as an inventor, thinker and angel investor. He's the driving force behind One Laptop per Child, building computers for children in the developing world.

talkTitle: A 30-year history of the future

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Sociologist and philosopher Renata Salecl scrutinizes our individual and societal neuroses, and suggests ways out of our current paralysis.

talkTitle: Our unhealthy obsession with choice

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Shih Chieh Huang doesn’t make art that’s meant to be admired from afar. He dissects and disassembles the detritus of our lives—household appliances, lights, computer parts, toys—and transforms them into surreal experiences.

talkTitle: Sculptures that’d be at home in the deep sea

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Heather Barnett creates art with slime mold -- a material used in diverse areas of scientific research, including biological computing, robotics and structural design.

talkTitle: What humans can learn from semi-intelligent slime

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ze Frank rose to fame on a viral video -- in 2001! He has been making online comedy, web toys and massively shared experiences (like the addictive Young Me Now Me) ever since.

talkTitle: Are you human?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Shai Reshef wants to democratize higher education.

talkTitle: An ultra-low-cost college degree
How animations can help scientists test a hypothesis

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Hubertus Knabe studies the history of torture, oppression and surveillance in former East Germany.

talkTitle: The dark secrets of a surveillance state

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Megan Washington has won two ARIA Awards, the Australian equivalent of the Grammys. A popular singer/songwriter, she has recently come clean with a secret—that she has a speech impediment.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Talithia Williams builds statistical models that study the spatial and temporal structure of data.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Eric Liu is founder of Citizen University, which teaches the art of powerful citizenship, and the executive director of the Aspen Institute Citizenship & American Identity Program.

talkTitle: Why ordinary people need to understand power

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jarrett J. Krosoczka is the author/illustrator of countless children's books and graphic novels, including Good Night, Monkey Boy, Baghead and the Lunch Lady series.

talkTitle: Why lunch ladies are heroes

speakerInfo.speakerBio: To help him come to terms with the tragedy of his own homeland, Bosnian photographer Ziyah Gafić turns his camera on the aftermath of conflict, showing his images in galleries, in books and on Instagram.

talkTitle: Everyday objects, tragic histories

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Aziza Chaouni focuses on projects that integrate architecture and landscape, and that ultimately give back to their communities. For years, she has worked to revive the Fez River, which runs through her hometown of Fez, Morocco.

talkTitle: How I brought a river, and my city, back to life

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Rose Goslinga isn’t your typical insurance salesperson. Through the Syngenta Foundation, her team developed insurance solutions to assist small-scale farmers in Africa, to safeguard their crops in case of droughts.

talkTitle: Crop insurance, an idea worth seeding

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Science historian Laurel Braitman is the author of Animal Madness, a book that takes a close look at our non-human friends and their mental anxieties.

talkTitle: Depressed dogs, cats with OCD — what animal madness means for us humans

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Andrew Connolly is helping to build the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope -- as well as tools to handle the massive datasets it will send our way.

talkTitle: What's the next window into our universe?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Isabel Allende writes stories of passion. Her novels and memoirs, including The House of the Spirits and Eva Luna, tell the stories of women and men who live with passionate commitment -- to love, to their world, to an ideal.

talkTitle: How to live passionately—no matter your age

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Why is there something rather than nothing? In his book "Why Does the World Exist?" Jim Holt dares to ask.

talkTitle: Why does the universe exist?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Shubhendu Sharma creates afforestation methods that make it easy to plant maintenance-free, wild and biodiverse forests.

talkTitle: An engineer's vision for tiny forests, everywhere

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Rishi Manchanda is an "upstreamist." A physician and public health innovator, he aims to reinvigorate primary care by teaching doctors to think about—and treat—the social and environmental conditions that often underly sickness.

talkTitle: What makes us get sick? Look upstream

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Using fMRI imaging to watch the human brain at work, Nancy Kanwisher’s team has discovered cortical regions responsible for some surprisingly specific elements of cognition.

talkTitle: A neural portrait of the human mind

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Dan Barasch’s grandmother grew up in New York’s Lower East Side. Now, he’s building an underground park in her old neighborhood, where greenspace is limited.

talkTitle: A park underneath the hustle and bustle of New York City

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In Hans Rosling’s hands, data sings. Global trends in health and economics come to vivid life. And the big picture of global development—with some surprisingly good news—snaps into sharp focus.

talkTitle: How not to be ignorant about the world

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Mac Barnett is a bestselling author of books for children.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Moshe Safdie's buildings -- from grand libraries to intimate apartment complexes -- explore the qualities of light and the nature of private and public space.

talkTitle: How to reinvent the apartment building

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Lord Nicholas Stern studies the economics of climate change. He is a co-author of the position paper presented to the UN's 2014 Climate Summit, called "The New Climate Economy."

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with Unilever.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Kenneth Cukier is the Data Editor of The Economist. From 2007 to 2012 he was the Tokyo correspondent, and before that, the paper’s technology correspondent in London, where his work focused on innovation, intellectual property and Internet governance. Kenneth is also the co-author of Big Data: A Revolution That Will Transform How We Live, Work, and Think with Viktor Mayer-Schönberger in 2013, which was a New York Times Bestseller and translated into 16 languages.

talkTitle: Big data is better data

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Eman Mohammed is a Palestinian photojournalist.

talkTitle: The courage to tell a hidden story

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Matthew O’Reilly is a veteran emergency medical technician on Long Island, New York.

talkTitle: “Am I dying?” The honest answer.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Francis de los Reyes works with cutting-edge microbiological techniques in environmental biotech. But his passion, both professionally and personally, is helping to improve the plight of the world’s 2.5 billion people living without adequate sanitation. Reyes is a TED Fellow.

talkTitle: Sanitation is a basic human right

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Susan Colantuono is the CEO and founder of Leading Women.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Daria van den Bercken has played piano with major Dutch orchestras, and performed many a recital in her country’s famed concert halls. But her larger vision is to bring classical music to the masses.

talkTitle: Why I take the piano on the road ... and in the air

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Meaghan Ramsey believes in business growth that stems from real social change.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with Unilever.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jeff Iliff is a neuroscientist who explores the unique functions of the brain.

talkTitle: One more reason to get a good night's sleep

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Glenn Greenwald is the journalist who has done the most to expose and explain the Edward Snowden files.

talkTitle: Why privacy matters

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jorge Soto is helping develop a simple, noninvasive test that identifies cancer.

talkTitle: The future of early cancer detection?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Melissa Fleming sheds light on their devastating plight and remarkable resilience of refugees.

talkTitle: Let's help refugees thrive, not just survive

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Kitra Cahana is a Canadian photographer who blurs the line between anthropologist and journalist.

talkTitle: My father, locked in his body but soaring free

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Susan Etlinger promotes the smart, well-considered and ethical use of data.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with IBM.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ghanaian Fred Swaniker founded a school and a leadership network to educate and support the next generation of Africa’s leaders.

talkTitle: The leaders who ruined Africa, and the generation who can fix it

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Fabien Cousteau spent 31 days underwater to research how climate change and pollution are affecting the oceans.

talkTitle: What I learned from spending 31 days underwater

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Frans Lanting is one of the greatest nature photographers of our time. His work has been featured in National Geographic, Audubon andTime, as well as numerous award-winning books. Lanting's recent exhibition, The LIFE Project, offers a lyrical interpretation of the history of life on Earth.

talkTitle: Photos that give voice to the animal kingdom

speakerInfo.speakerBio: American lawyer Kimberley Motley is the only Western litigator in Afghanistan's courts; as her practice expands to other countries, she thinks deeply about how to build the capacity of rule of law globally.

talkTitle: How I defend the rule of law

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Sergei Lupashin imagines new uses for flying robots. He's a 2014 TED Fellow.

talkTitle: A flying camera ... on a leash

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Debra Jarvis isn't your typical hospital chaplain. With wry wit, she aims to comfort patients -- and also challenge them.

talkTitle: Yes, I survived cancer. But that doesn't define me

speakerInfo.speakerBio: At Purpose, Jeremy Heimans strategizes how to harness new social, economic and technological models to build movements with impact.

talkTitle: What new power looks like

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A columnist for Forbes, Kare Anderson writes on behavioral research-based ways to become more deeply connected.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with IBM.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ilona Szabó de Carvalho leads the Igarapé Institute in Rio de Janeiro, which focuses on security and development policy.

talkTitle: 4 lessons I learned from taking a stand against drugs and gun violence

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ad exec Jose Miguel Sokoloff has led a multi-year marketing campaign that's helped Colombian guerrillas realize that they are wanted back home.

talkTitle: How Christmas lights helped guerrillas put down their guns

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ameenah Gurib-Fakim is the president of the Republic of Mauritius. She has been a university professor and entrepreneur before her election as the first female Head of State of Mauritius.

talkTitle: Humble plants that hide surprising secrets

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Alejandro Aravena works inside paradoxes, seeing space and flexibility in public housing, clarity in economic scarcity, and the keys to rebuilding in the causes of natural disasters. He

talkTitle: My architectural philosophy? Bring the community into the process

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Working as Haas&Hahn, artists Jeroen Koolhaas and Dre Urhahn splash color onto urban walls -- and train young painters in the process.

talkTitle: How painting can transform communities

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ethan Nadelmann has ushered the once-marginal issue of drug legalization onto the center stage of US political debate.

talkTitle: Why we need to end the War on Drugs

speakerInfo.speakerBio: At the Center for Disease Dynamics, Economics & Policy, economist Ramanan Laxminarayan looks at big-picture issues of global health.

talkTitle: The coming crisis in antibiotics

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Dr. Leana Wen is Baltimore City's Health Commissioner.

talkTitle: What your doctor won’t disclose

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Michael Green is part of the team that has created the Social Progress Index, a standard to rank societies based on how they meet the needs of citizens.

talkTitle: What the Social Progress Index can reveal about your country

speakerInfo.speakerBio: David Grady is on a crusade to help you take back your calendar.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with State Street Boston.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Rosie King challenges stereotypes of people with autism and contextualizes the issue by asking us, “Why be normal?”

talkTitle: How autism freed me to be myself

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Nancy Frates and her family have raised a projected $160 million for ALS research in 2014. How? They kicked off the ALS Ice Bucket Challenge to honor 29-year-old Pete Frates.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Joe Landolina is a TED Fellow and the inventor of VETI-GEL.

talkTitle: This gel can make you stop bleeding instantly

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Robert Muggah creates tools to understand cycles of violence in urban environments and opens dialogues on ways to confront them globally.

talkTitle: How to protect fast-growing cities from failing

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Social psychologist Emily Balcetis explores perception, motivation, goal-setting and decision-making from conscious and nonconscious levels.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As fast as the rainforest is disappearing -- the people of the rainforest are disappearing even faster. Mark Plotkin works to preserve generations of knowledge.

talkTitle: What the people of the Amazon know that you don't

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Videre co-founder Oren Yakobovich wields the latest covert recording technology to expose and subvert violent oppression.

talkTitle: Hidden cameras that film injustice in the world’s most dangerous places

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In 2004, Ben Saunders became the youngest person ever to ski solo to the North Pole. In 2013, he set out on another record-breaking expedition, this time to retrace Captain Scott’s ill-fated journey to the South Pole on foot.

talkTitle: To the South Pole and back — the hardest 105 days of my life

speakerInfo.speakerBio: BCG's Rainer Strack advocates for companies to adopt a "people advantage" -- because employee-centered thinking can go a long way.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with BCG Berlin.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Anastasia Taylor-Lind is a documentary photographer who works around the world on issues relating to women, birth rights, depopulation and post-conflict regions.

talkTitle: Fighters and mourners of the Ukrainian revolution

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Thomas Hellum is an award-winning television producer who works at NRK Hordaland in Norway.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Catherine Crump is an assistant clinical professor at Berkeley Law School who focuses on the laws around data and surveillance.

talkTitle: The small and surprisingly dangerous detail the police track about you

speakerInfo.speakerBio: The co-host of TEDxMidAtlantic, Dave Troy is a serial entrepreneur and a data-viz fan.

talkTitle: Social maps that reveal a city's intersections — and separations

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Vernā Myers is dedicated to promoting meaningful, lasting diversity in the workplace.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: In the tribal region where she was born, Khalida Brohi founded an organization to end honor killings and empower Pakistani women.

talkTitle: How I work to protect women from honor killings

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Hannah Fry researches the trends in our civilization and ways we can forecast its future.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Journalist and photographer Bruno Torturra is the face of Media Ninja, a Brazilian digital collective making headlines for its ability to cover big news as it happens.

talkTitle: Got a smartphone? Start broadcasting

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jeremy Howard imagines how advanced machine learning can improve our lives.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Carol Dweck is a pioneering researcher in the field of motivation, why people succeed (or don't) and how to foster success.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Mundano's bold, colorful street art isn't just eye candy. His projects call attention to social, environmental and political issues, while raising chuckles from passersby.

talkTitle: Trash cart superheroes

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Computer scientist Michael Rubinstein and his team have developed a "motion microscope" that can show video footage of barely perceivable movements, like breaths and heartbeats.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Dedicated to increasing awareness about Northern Indian Ocean blue whales, Asha de Vos is also committed to inspiring the next generation of marine biologists.

talkTitle: Why you should care about whale poo

speakerInfo.speakerBio: At Yahoo! Labs in Barcelona, Daniele Quercia and his colleagues imagine new ways to use online maps to improve our lives.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with BCG Berlin.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Cristina Domenech proposes to use language as an instrument of liberation and as a way to change the world.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Fredy Peccerelli works with families whose loved ones “disappeared” in the 36-year armed conflict in Guatemala. The executive director of the Guatemalan Forensic Anthropology Foundation, he helps locate bodies and give back identities to those buried in mass graves.

talkTitle: A forensic anthropologist who brings closure for the "disappeared"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Robert Swan has explored both poles, and wants to make sure that Antarctica, the world's last great wilderness, is never exploited.

talkTitle: Let's save the last pristine continent

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Bassam Tariq delights in making eclectic career choices. A blogger, a filmmaker, and a butcher's shop owner, the common theme linking everything together is his boundless celebration of humanity.

talkTitle: The beauty and diversity of Muslim life

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Sarah Bergbreiter packs advanced technologies into tiny robots that can overcome obstacles 80 times their height.

talkTitle: Why I make robots the size of a grain of rice

speakerInfo.speakerBio: A human resources activist, Morgana Bailey wants to see the diversity of society reflected in the workplace, and employees of all walks of life feel comfortable being open about who they are.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with State Street London.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Miguel Nicolelis explores the limits of the brain-machine interface.

talkTitle: Brain-to-brain communication has arrived. How we did it

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Joe Madiath brings Indian villagers together around water and sanitation projects.

talkTitle: Better toilets, better life

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Severine Autesserre traces civil war and endemic violence to its roots, and its resolution, in local and interpersonal conflicts.

talkTitle: To solve mass violence, look to locals

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Khadija Gbla was born in Sierra Leone, spent her youth in Gambia, and as a teenager put down roots in Australia. She uses her cross-cultural heritage to promote understanding in both directions.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Techno-sociologist Zeynep Tufekci asks big questions about our societies and our lives, as both algorithms and digital connectivity spread.

talkTitle: Online social change: easy to organize, hard to win

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As the Assistant Director-General of the World Health Organization’s Polio and Emergencies Cluster, Bruce Aylward works to ensure that polio stays under control and that the world is prepared to respond to health crises.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Tom Wujec studies how we share and absorb information. He's an innovative practitioner of business visualization -- using design and technology to help groups solve problems and understand ideas. He is a Fellow at Autodesk.

talkTitle: Got a wicked problem? First, tell me how you make toast

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Artist Brian Dettmer digs into a good book (literally, with a knife) to create beautifully intricate forms that reflect how we see old information in a modern world.

talkTitle: Old books reborn as art

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jaap de Roode studies the ecology and evolution of parasites, focusing on those that attack the monarch butterfly.

talkTitle: How butterflies self-medicate

speakerInfo.speakerBio: With Architizer, an online hub for architecture, Marc Kushner is breaking architecture out of its insular echo chamber and reconnecting the public with buildings.

talkTitle: Why the buildings of the future will be shaped by ... you

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Kenneth Shinozuka designs smart products ... He's been doing so since he was in kindergarten.

talkTitle: My simple invention, designed to keep my grandfather safe

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Guy Winch asks us to take our emotional health as seriously as we take our physical health -- and explores how to heal from common heartaches.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Nadine Burke Harris’ healthcare practice focuses on a little-understood, yet very common factor in childhood that can profoundly impact adult-onset disease: trauma.

talkTitle: How childhood trauma affects health across a lifetime

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Laura Boushnak is a Kuwaiti-born Palestinian photographer whose work focuses on women, literacy and education reform in the Arab world.

talkTitle: For these women, reading is a daring act

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Angelo Vermeulen wears many hats, including one as a crew commander for NASA, another as an artist and community organizer.

talkTitle: How to go to space, without having to go to space

speakerInfo.speakerBio: James A. White Sr. believes that every person and organization has incredible potential. He works to help them understand it — and communicate it to others.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ben Wellington blends his love of statistics, the city, and comedy in his entertaining analysis of the story of New York City, told through data.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Bel Pesce left Brazil to study at MIT. But after a successful stint in Silicon Valley, she returned to inspire others with great ideas in her country to make them a reality.

talkTitle: 5 ways to kill your dreams

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Rob Knight explores the unseen microbial world that exists literally right under our noses -- and everywhere else on (and in) our bodies.

talkTitle: How our microbes make us who we are

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Through his startup Rainforest Connection, Topher White transforms used cell phones into guardians of the rainforest.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Andy Yen is building an encrypted email program that lets everyone benefit from private communication.

talkTitle: Think your email's private? Think again

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Using a deck of cards and other simple props, Helder Guimarães gets up close to play with your perceptions and preconceptions.

talkTitle: A magical search for a coincidence

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Shimpei Takahashi thinks we should forget about analyzing data or sales figures and just come up with ideas -- lots and lots of ideas.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

She worked as a teacher and a missionary in a university for future leaders -- all while writing her book.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: With his membership platform Patreon, YouTube star Jack Conte may have solved a perennial problem of content creators -- getting paid for digital media.

talkTitle: How artists can (finally) get paid in the digital age

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Through his writing and his realized projects, Peter Calthorpe has spread the vision of New Urbanism, a framework for creating sustainable, human-scaled places.

talkTitle: 7 principles for building better cities

speakerInfo.speakerBio: As co-creator of Siri, Tom Gruber helped redefine the role of machine intelligence in our lives and transformed the way we interact with our devices.

talkTitle: How AI can enhance our memory, work and social lives

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Susan Pinker reveals how in-person social interactions are not only necessary for human happiness but also could be a key to health and longevity.

talkTitle: The secret to living longer may be your social life

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ashton Applewhite asks us to look at ageism -- the assumption that older people are alike and that aging impoverishes us.

talkTitle: Let's end ageism

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Anika Paulson’s love for music permeates her understanding of herself, her surroundings and the mysteries that make up the smallest and biggest parts of life.

talkTitle: How I found myself through music

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Data skeptic Cathy O’Neil uncovers the dark secrets of big data, showing how our "objective" algorithms could in fact reinforce human bias.

talkTitle: The era of blind faith in big data must end

speakerInfo.speakerBio: David Baron writes about science in books, magazines, newspapers and for public radio. He formerly served as science correspondent for NPR and science editor for PRI’s The World.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Professor Carolyn Bertozzi is a chemical biologist who invents technologies and medicines based on disease-causing sugar molecules.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jon Boogz is a movement artist, choreographer and director who seeks to push the evolution of dance.

talkTitle: A dance to honor Mother Earth

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Could an AI pass the entrance exam for the University of Tokyo? Noriko Arai oversees a project that wants to find out.

talkTitle: Can a robot pass a university entrance exam?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Through his mesmerizing satellite photographs, Benjamin Grant offers us a new way of seeing of our planet and ourselves.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Chance Coughenour is recreating heritage and culture that's been lost throughout the world.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: With his futuristic artworks, Daan Roosegaarde illuminates the intersection of technology, humanity and our urban environments.

talkTitle: A smog vacuum cleaner and other magical city designs

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Dr. Erin Marie Saltman manages Facebook's counterterrorism and counter-extremism policy work for Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Wanuri Kahiu wants to curate, commission and create art that celebrates fun, fierce and frivolous Africa.

talkTitle: Fun, fierce and fantastical African art

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Does humanity have a future as uploaded minds? In his work, Robin Hanson asks this and other extra-large questions.

talkTitle: What would happen if we upload our brains to computers?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Ray Dalio is the founder, chair and co-chief investment officer of Bridgewater Associates, a global leader in institutional portfolio management and the largest hedge fund in the world.

talkTitle: How to build a company where the best ideas win

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Arik Hartmann is tackling the ignorance and misinformation surrounding HIV/AIDS.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Dr. Helen Czerski investigates the physics of ocean bubbles and spends a lot of time sharing the big scientific ideas hidden in the small objects around us.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Laolu Senbanjo's motto is: “Everything is my canvas.”

talkTitle: "The Sacred Art of the Ori"

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Chetan Bhatt teaches and writes about the numerous dangers human rights face today from resurgent Far Right movements.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Jennifer Granick fights for civil liberties in the age of surveillance and powerful digital technology.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Augie Picado is the country manager for UPS Mexico.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with UPS.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Elizabeth Blackburn won a Nobel Prize for her pioneering work on telomeres and telomerase, which may play central roles in how we age. She is president of the Salk Institute and author of the New York Times Best Seller, "The Telomere Effect."

talkTitle: The science of cells that never get old

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Taking cues from bottom-up biological networks like those of social insects, Radhika Nagpal helped design an unprecedented “swarm” of ant-like robots.

talkTitle: What intelligent machines can learn from a school of fish

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Writing on urban development, sexual and reproductive rights, gender and queerness, OluTimehin Adegbeye resists marginalization by reminding her audiences of the validity of every human experience.

talkTitle: Who belongs in a city?

speakerInfo.speakerBio: TED Resident Anindya Kundu is reframing our notions of achievement and ability through his sociological research, which suggests all students can succeed if provided the right support systems.

talkTitle: The boost students need to overcome obstacles

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Pierre Thiam shares the cuisine of his home in Senegal through global restaurants and highly praised cookbooks.

talkTitle: A forgotten ancient grain that could help Africa prosper
Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: UPS's Julio Gil thinks that technology is flipping the equation on future cities, and that rural may soon become the new urban.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TED-curated event in partnership with UPS.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Anna Heringer’s sustainable designs lend breathtaking forms to easily-available local materials while developing the skills and consciousness of their builders.

talkTitle: The warmth and wisdom of mud buildings

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Drawing on a rich cultural and personal history, Olúfẹ́mi Táíwò studies philosophy of law, social and political philosophy, Marxism, and African and Africana philosophy.

talkTitle: Why Africa must become a center of knowledge again

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Inspired by classic city simulation games, Finnish designer Karoliina Korppoo and her fellow game developers at Colossal Order are infusing a venerable gaming genre with fresh perspectives.

talkTitle: How a video game might help us build better cities

speakerInfo.speakerBio: With his "Microsculpture" series, Levon Biss photographs the incredible details of insects.

talkTitle: Mind-blowing, magnified portraits of insects

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Gabriela González is part of the collaboration of more than 1,000 scientists who measured for the first time the gravitational waves that Einstein predicted over 100 years ago.

talkTitle: How LIGO discovered gravitational waves — and what might be next

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Theo E.J. Wilson encourages us to break through the divides that separate us.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Working across disciplines, Chika Ezeanya-Esiobu explores homegrown and grassroots approaches to the sustainable advancement of Sub-Saharan Africa.

talkTitle: How Africa can use its traditional knowledge to make progress

speakerInfo.speakerBio: TED Fellow Prumsodun Ok heals, empowers and advocates using the ancient art of Khmer classical dance.

talkTitle: The magic of Khmer classical dance

speakerInfo.speakerBio: Euna Lee strives to be a voice for the voiceless and a window for those with no access to outside information.

talkTitle: Editor's note: This talk was recorded at a TEDx event organized by volunteers; speakers are selected independently of TED.
